head.title: Autopsy Is Inconclusive In Boy's Death on Bus

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: Autopsy Is Inconclusive In Boy's Death on Bus

abstract.p: NYC medical examiner's office says that autopsy has not determined cause of death of Anthony Anselm, 11-year-old Queens boy who was found dead on his school bus; says further tests are necessary (S)

block.p: The medical examiner's office said yesterday that an autopsy had not determined the cause of death of an 11-year-old Queens boy who was found dead Monday morning on his school bus, and that further tests were necessary.

A bus matron found the boy, Anthony Anselm of Hollis, unconscious in his seat shortly after 8 a.m., when the bus arrived at the Walter Reed School in Maspeth. A school nurse and others tried to revive him, but he was taken to Elmhurst Hospital and pronounced dead about an hour later.

The medical examiner's office said yesterday that an autopsy had not determined the cause of death of an 11-year-old Queens boy who was found dead Monday morning on his school bus, and that further tests were necessary.

A bus matron found the boy, Anthony Anselm of Hollis, unconscious in his seat shortly after 8 a.m., when the bus arrived at the Walter Reed School in Maspeth. A school nurse and others tried to revive him, but he was taken to Elmhurst Hospital and pronounced dead about an hour later.

METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK Correction: May 25, 2000, Thursday Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about New York City's efforts to suspend the license of a tour company after one of its buses killed a pedestrian misstated the surname of the victim in some copies. He was Randolph Walker, not Walter.
